messages.content:
<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technology -- Safety evaluation criteria) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products, possessing scientific, universal, and scalable characteristics, which can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, modification, or destruction. Safety requirements may include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical/electronic systems performing specific safety functions to achieve or maintain a safe state for the system in the event of a specific hazardous event.
Safety analysis criteria may contain content that is irrelevant or unsuitable for the current needs. It is necessary to remove the irrelevant parts through a filter to ensure the effectiveness of the safety analysis.

<<< Objective >>>
Filter out irrelevant or unsuitable safety analysis criteria, retaining only those that meet the current requirements.

<<< Style >>>
Precise, concise.

<<< Specific Requirements >>>
Accept some safety analysis criteria, determine if filtering is needed. If so, remove irrelevant sentences or paragraphs and output the criteria that meet the functional requirements; otherwise, do not filter the original content.
No explanation needed

<<< Input Example 1 >>>

{  
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",  
    "Airborne software"  
  ]  
}

<<< Output Example 1 >>>

```json
{  
  "need_filter": true,
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms."  
  ]  
}
```

<<< Input Example 2 >>>

{  
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",  
    "Check the data bits with a discrete value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the data bits take values such as \"each enumerated value in the valid range\"."  
  ]  
}

<<< Output Example 2 >>>

```json
{  
  "need_filter": false,
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",
    "Check the data bits with a discrete value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the data bits take values such as \"each enumerated value in the valid range\"." 
  ]  
}
```

<<< Input >>>

{"safety_criterions": ["In the interface data", "Check the data bits with a continuous value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output in cases such as \"boundary values, maximum/minimum values\".", "Check the data bits with a discrete value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output in cases such as \"each enumerated value in the valid range\".", "Check the data bits with a discrete value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output in cases such as \"undefined abnormal values outside the valid range\".", "External interface fault mode-data analysis", "In the interface data", "Check the data bits with a continuous value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the difference between data values over multiple cycles exceeds the specified threshold (i.e., slope fault)."]}

<<< Output >>>

```json
{
    "need_filter": true,
    "safety_criterions": [
        "Check the data bits with a continuous value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output in cases such as \"boundary values, maximum/minimum values\".",
        "Check the data bits with a discrete value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output in cases such as \"each enumerated value in the valid range\".",
        "Check the data bits with a discrete value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output in cases such as \"undefined abnormal values outside the valid range\".",
        "Check the data bits with a continuous value range in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the difference between data values over multiple cycles exceeds the specified threshold (i.e., slope fault)."
    ]
}
```

These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, modification, or destruction. Safety requirements may include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical/electronic systems performing specific safety functions to achieve or maintain a safe state for the system in the event of a specific hazardous event.

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technology -- Safety evaluation criteria) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products, possessing scientific, universal, and scalable characteristics, which can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, modification, or destruction. Safety requirements may include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical/electronic systems performing specific safety functions to achieve or maintain a safe state for the system in the event of a specific hazardous event.
Safety analysis criteria may contain content that is irrelevant or unsuitable for the current needs. It is necessary to remove the irrelevant parts through a filter to ensure the effectiveness of the safety analysis.

<<< Objective >>>
Filter out irrelevant or unsuitable safety analysis criteria, retaining only those that meet the current requirements.

<<< Style >>>
Precise, concise.

<<< Specific Requirements >>>

These requirements are designed to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, privacy protection, etc. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to enable the system to reach or maintain a safe state under certain hazardous events.

Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their life cycle. These criteria cover various stages of the product from development, production, integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functions and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information Technology Security Evaluation Criteria) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods of IT products, which is scientific, universal and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
A safety requirement is a condition or capability that a system or product must meet to ensure its safety. These requirements are designed to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, privacy protection, etc. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to enable the system to reach or maintain a safe state under certain hazardous events.

Safety requirements can include identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, privacy protection, etc. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to enable the system to reach or maintain a safe state under certain hazardous events.
There may be some irrelevant or unsuitable content in the safety analysis criteria for the current needs, and the irrelevant parts need to be removed through a filter to ensure the effectiveness of the safety analysis.

<<< Goal >>>
Filter out irrelevant or unsuitable safety analysis criteria, and only keep the criteria that meet the current needs.

<<< Style >>>
Precise and concise.

<<< Specific Requirements >>>

Accept some safety analysis criteria, judge whether filtering is needed, if so, remove the irrelevant sentences or paragraphs, and output the criteria that meet the functional requirements, otherwise do not filter the original content
No explanation needed

<<< Input Example 1 >>>

{  
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure that all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",  
    "Airborne software"  
  ]  
}

<<< Output Example 1 >>>

```json
{  
  "need_filter": true
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure that all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms."  
  ]  
}
```

<<< Input Example 2 >>>

{  
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure that all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",  
    "Check the data bits with discrete value ranges in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the data bit value is each enumeration value of the valid value range"  
  ]  
}

<<< Output Example 2 >>>

```json
{  
  "need_filter": false
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure that all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",
    "Check the data bits with discrete value ranges in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the data bit value is each enumeration value of the valid value range" 
  ]  
}
```

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their life cycle. These criteria cover various stages of the product from development, production, integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functions and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information Technology Security Evaluation Criteria) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods of IT products, which is scientific, universal and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
A safety requirement is a condition or capability that a system or product must meet to ensure its safety. These requirements are designed to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, privacy protection, etc. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to enable the system to reach or maintain a safe state under certain hazardous events.

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their life cycle. These criteria cover various stages of the product from development, production, integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functions and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information Technology Security Evaluation Criteria) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods of IT products, which is scientific, universal and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
A safety requirement is a condition or capability that a system or product must meet to ensure its safety. These requirements are designed to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, privacy protection, etc. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to enable the system to reach or maintain a safe state under certain hazardous events.

Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their entire lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.
Safety analysis criteria may contain content that is irrelevant or unsuitable for the current needs. It is necessary to use a filter to remove the irrelevant parts to ensure the effectiveness of the safety analysis.

<<< Goal >>>
Filter out irrelevant or unsuitable safety analysis criteria, retaining only those that meet the current requirements.

<<< Style >>>
Precise, concise.

<<< Specific Requirements >>>

Accept some safety analysis criteria, determine if filtering is needed. If so, remove irrelevant sentences or paragraphs and output the criteria that meet functional requirements. Otherwise, do not filter the original content.
No explanation needed.

<<< Input Example 1 >>>

{  
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",  
    "Airborne software"  
  ]  
}

<<< Output Example 1 >>>

```json
{  
  "need_filter": true,
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms."  
  ]  
}
```

<<< Input Example 2 >>>

{  
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",  
    "Check the data bits with discrete value ranges in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the data bit value is one of 'each enumerated value of the valid domain', etc."
  ]  
}

<<< Output Example 2 >>>

```json
{  
  "need_filter": false,
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",
    "Check the data bits with discrete value ranges in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the data bit value is one of 'each enumerated value of the valid domain', etc."
  ]  
}
```

<<< Input >>>

{"safety_criterions": ["10. Other Design Considerations (YJCLSJ)", "Software should cooperate with hard...", "During a power failure or power-down, the software must provide a safe and appropriate shutdown to prevent potentially unsafe states from occurring", "The software design must consider performing system-level checks when the system is powered on to verify that the system is safe and functioning normally; when possible, the software should perform periodic checks on the system to monitor the system's safety status", "10. Other Design Considerations (YJCLSJ)"]}

<<< Output >>>

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their entire lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their entire lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.
Safety analysis criteria may contain content that is irrelevant or unsuitable for the current needs. It is necessary to use a filter to remove the irrelevant parts to ensure the effectiveness of the safety analysis.

<<< Goal >>>
Filter out irrelevant or unsuitable safety analysis criteria, retaining only those that meet the current requirements.

<<< Style >>>
Precise, concise.

<<< Specific Requirements >>>

Accept some safety analysis criteria, determine if filtering is needed. If so, remove irrelevant sentences or paragraphs and output the criteria that meet functional requirements. Otherwise, do not filter the original content.
No explanation needed.

<<< Input Example 1 >>>

{  
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",  
    "Airborne software"  
  ]  
}

<<< Output Example 1 >>>

```json
{  
  "need_filter": true,
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms."  
  ]  
}
```

<<< Input Example 2 >>>

{  
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",  
    "Check the data bits with discrete value ranges in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the data bit value is one of 'each enumerated value of the valid domain', etc."
  ]  
}

<<< Output Example 2 >>>

```json
{  
  "need_filter": false,
  "safety_criterions": [  
    "Ensure all interfaces have appropriate authentication mechanisms.",
    "Check the data bits with discrete value ranges in the interface data, and analyze the correctness of the output when the data bit value is one of 'each enumerated value of the valid domain', etc."
  ]  
}
```

<<< Input >>>

{"safety_criterions": ["Arrays are prohibited from going out of bounds", "Array subscripts must be integers greater than or equal to zero"]}

<<< Output >>>

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their entire lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their entire lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their entire lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.

<<< Background >>>
Safety analysis criteria are general requirements and methods that guide the safety assessment of information technology products throughout their entire lifecycle. These criteria cover various stages of a product, from development, production, and integration to operation and maintenance, aiming to ensure that the product meets specific safety functional and assurance requirements. For example, the GB/T 18336 standard (Information technologySafety techniquesEvaluation criteria for IT safety) comprehensively elaborates on the safety requirements and evaluation methods for IT products. It is scientific, universal, and extensible, and can be used to guide the development and evaluation of products or systems.
Safety requirements refer to the conditions or capabilities that a system or product must satisfy to ensure its safety. These requirements are intended to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data, and to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or destruction. Safety requirements can include aspects such as identification, authentication, authorization, data integrity, intrusion detection, non-repudiation, and privacy protection. For example, functional safety requirements may involve safety-related electrical and electronic systems performing specific safety functions to bring the system to or maintain a safe state in the event of a specific hazardous event.
Safety analysis criteria may contain content that is irrelevant or unsuitable for the current needs. It is necessary to use a filter to remove the irrelevant parts to ensure the effectiveness of the safety analysis.
